documentType: Bureau of Prisons Suicide Risk Assessment
summary: This is a Bureau of Prisons psychological assessment of Jeffrey Epstein conducted on July 9, 2019, the day after a court proceeding. The assessment, performed by a chief psychologist, evaluates Epstein's suicide risk, finding it low, and details his mental status, history, and future orientation. It notes he was placed on precautionary psychological observation due to his high-profile case and recent court appearance.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the suicide risk assessment. He is a 66-year-old inmate charged with sex trafficking, assessed after returning from a court proceeding. He denies any suicidal ideation, expresses future orientation, and discusses his business, attorney, and upcoming bail hearing.

persons.name: PhD/Chief Psychologist
persons.context: The author and conducting clinician of the suicide risk assessment and diagnostic formulation for inmate Jeffrey Epstein. The psychologist interviews Epstein, evaluates his risk factors, and makes housing and monitoring recommendations.

persons.name: Miner Basso
persons.context: Appears as the generator of an amended version of the suicide risk assessment on July 10, 2019. Likely the same individual as the 'PhD/Chief Psychologist'.

persons.name: Epstein's Brother
persons.context: Mentioned by Epstein as his only family, with whom he does not have a close relationship. This lack of close family connection is listed as a static risk factor for suicide.

persons.name: Epstein's Attorney
persons.context: Referenced by Epstein, who expresses confidence in him, describes him as 'competent,' and requests a meeting with him during the assessment.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: A Bureau of Prisons chief psychologist conducts a formal suicide risk assessment on Jeffrey Epstein. The assessment finds acute suicide risk is 'Low' and chronic risk 'Absent,' leading to a recommendation against a suicide watch.

events.title: Placement on Psychological Observation
events.description: Epstein is placed on psychological observation status upon returning from court on July 8, as a precaution due to his risk factors (high-profile case, sex charges).

events.description: The suicide risk assessment document is amended by Miner Basso, PhD/Chief Psychologist.

keyFacts: On July 9, 2019, a BOP psychologist assessed Jeffrey Epstein's suicide risk as 'Low' and chronic risk as 'Absent,' recommending against a suicide watch.

Epstein was placed on precautionary psychological observation after a court proceeding on July 8, 2019, due to risk factors including his high-profile case, sex trafficking charges, and potential bad legal news.
Epstein explicitly denied any past or present suicidal ideation, intention, or plan, and presented as future-oriented, discussing an upcoming bail hearing and his business.
Epstein reported his only family was a brother with whom he had no close relationship, a noted static risk factor.
The assessment states Epstein had previously served time in Palm Beach County jail on soliciting prostitution charges and was currently facing federal sex trafficking charges.
